Message.Title: bearish signal
Message.Msg: Unemployment goes up market Rallies. GDP shrinks by 3 percent in a quarter market rallies. Average unemployment is US is more like 20 percent. taxes hitting the middle class. We are almost at $4.00 a gallon for gas. FEDS balance sheet is crushed. Real estate sales way down. massive layoffs coming from the Government is 4 weeks. Interest rates rising . The percentage of working-age Americans who are either employed or actively in search of a job was reported as 63.6 percent for November 2012, two percentage points lower than the previous month and the worst the country has seen since 1978. With the release of the monthly jobs numbers from the Labor Department on Friday, the White House has touted the latest figure — an unemployment rate of 7.7 down from October’s 7.9 — as an indicator of their success in a promise to push that statistic down. In reality, though, fewer residents with an actual interest and ability to work are employed as ever before. The labor force participation rate has now been at or below 66.0 percent since the country entered a recession in late 2007. While the White House is celebrating the lowest unemployment numbers in the history of the Obama administration, other statistics suggest the scope of the jobs market remains as grim as ever. Indeed, the number of Americans without jobs in the eyes of the Labor Department has shrunk two percentage points, but the proportion of Americans who are actively seeking employment as at its lowest in ages. According to the government, another 350,000 Americans left the labor force during November, and when you keep pretending that huge chunks of workers ‘disappear’ each month it is easy to get the ‘unemployment rate’ to go down,” wrote economy blogger Michael Snyder, who acknowledges that the number of Americans “not in the labor force” has grown by almost 8.5 million since the Obama administration began . Not a bad job for a guy who will not release is college or graduate transcripts.

Topic.Title: bearish signal

Message.Msg: heres the real deal. Where does that number come from? Right now, there are 12.3 million unemployed Americans. When the economy was running at full blast at the end of 2007, there were just 7.7 million unemployed — in transition or switching between jobs, say. But on top of that, the population also keeps growing, currently adding about 88,000 new people to the labor force each month. Put all that together, and it will take about 9 years to close the “jobs gap” — to get back to the ratio of payrolls to working-age population that prevailed back in December 2007. Looks like we all get another teax increase before this year out. We need 5 trillion for an interest only payment which was due dec 2012 and we need 3 trillion for 2013 budget. that brings the deficit to how much????? ......

Message.Title: DOW back to 2007 HIGH of 14,000(CAREFUL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!)
Message.Msg: All of the talking heads on television are excited about the stock market’s current level: the Dow is oh-so-close to the 2007 high. So I thought about 2007 and wondered if anyone would have thought the following would be happening right now, AND that the stock market would be at the same level – and soon to be higher. Much higher unemployment that now seems to be structurally higher (not coming down). Highest amount of citizens ever on welfare – food stamps – with a now politically correct name of SNAP. Massive home devaluation. Massive evictions across the entire country. Corporate earnings not exactly the best. GDP less than zero – contraction! Deficit spending greater than $1Trillion…every year. Debt-to-GDP ratio in banana republic territory: 103.8%. Nearly every Western country on the globe is insolvent. A French labor minister recently admitted that France “…is a totally bankrupt state.”(kinda like USofA) If this was foretold; would you also believe that the market RALLIED over 100%? Surely, in 2007, you would have thought it impossible but it is a reality. Send your thank you cards and warm wishes to Ben Bernanke at the Fed. Long live Corporatism and financial socialism.

Topic.Title: Dividend Increase...

Message.Msg: The BoD can vote all they want. They do not have the power to up the divi. Only the regulators have it. Furthermore, any request to up it has to be made to those regulators. BAC does not earn enough profit to merit an increase in divi. With a float of 10B shares, it's way more important to buy back shares than increase the divi from one cent to four. The point of having all the BASIL III capital requirements is to keep it as a base, not give it back to the shareholders. I would not expect much of a divi increase and hope to see as large a share buyback as posible. Think about it. If BAC could remove 1B shares, your share price goes up about 1.72. Get it?
